results.description:
On sale  $19.98

For just $25 taste 6 gorgeous domestic wines, suitable for your Thanksgiving table, accompanied by assorted cheeses & charcuterie. Our focus will be wines from Oregon (Argyle), the Sonoma Coast of California (MacRostie) & Alexander Valley in Sonoma (Nick Goldschmidt). 

From these iconic & critically acclaimed producers we will taste an Argyle Sparkling wine made Méthode Champenoise as well as an Argyle Chardonnay & Pinot Noir. From MacRostie we will taste a Chardonnay & Pinot Noir.  And from Nick Goldschmidt we will taste Fidelity, a Meritage blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon & Petit Verdot. The vineyards that produce these wines are situated in three of the best regions on the west coast for the production of wines made from these grapes.


We are fortunate to have as our very special guest host for the evening the very sharp, dynamic, knowledgeable & quite witty wine professional, Michael Metzger. Michael Metzger has been an active member in the hospitality industry since 2004 holding positions from waiter, cellar hand, sommelier, and wine director in New York City, Boston, The US Virgin islands, Mendoza Argentina, and the Yarra Valley in Australia. As wine director of Vic & Anthony’s Steakhouse on Park Avenue South in NYC, his wine list was awarded a ‘Best of Award of Excellence” from the Wine Spectator. Michael has also studied advanced blind tasting courses with Andrew Bell, founder of the American Sommelier Association. He currently works as a Regional Sales Manager for Distinguished Vineyards & Wine Partners, owners of Argyle Winery in the Willamette Valley and MacRostie Winery in the Sonoma Coast.

Please join Michael Metzger for this casual wine tasting exploring wines with appropriate balance to grace any Thanksgiving table.

While various cheeses, charcuterie & breads will be served, you may wish to order appetizers or a full dinner. There are several fine restaurants nearby that deliver. Menus will be available.

All wines tasted will be available for purchase.

Here’s the line-up…

Argyle Brut Sparkling Wine 2011, Willamette Valley, Oregon
MacRostie Chardonnay 2013, Sonoma Coast, CA
Argyle Nuthouse Chardonnay 2010, Willamette Valley, Oregon
Argyle Pinot Noir 2013, Willamette Valley, Oregon
MacRostie Pinot Noir 2012, Sonoma Coast, CA         Fidelity Meritage 2013                                                      Mystery Wine… Two Brunellos d'Montalcino!!!!

Tasting Notes, Retail Prices & Winery & Vineyard History:

Argyle Brut 2011          on sale:   $19.98

Willamette Valley, Oregon
www.dvwinepartners.com
www.argylewinery.com 2010 Vintage:
91 Pts – Robert Parker’s Wine Advocate
The 2011 Brut is a blend of 60% Pinot Noir & 40% Chardonnay undergoing 5% malolactic fermentation and disgorged in September 2014. It was matured in 20% neutral oak and 80% stainless steel. It has a vibrant citrus-driven bouquet that is well defined and offers a little touch of peach with aeration. The palate is well balanced with crisp acidity, touches of brioche and pineapple with a fresh, vivacious finish. Excellent - and great value, too.

90 Pts – Wine Spectator
Light & appealing, with an airy texture & smoky, toasty watermelon & floral flavors, finishing with expressiveness & length.

Since its first vintage in 1987, Argyle Brut has always been vintage-dated, 100% Argyle-grown and was the first in the US to use late-season ripening Dijon Clones. Argyle is the Pacific Northwest's Most Celebrated Sparkling wine producer.

Crafted from the Willamette Valley's coolest growing season on record, 2011 Vintage Brut offers all you can ask for in true cool-climate sparkling wine. The delicate bouquet is filled with red berry spice, lemon blossom & toasted brioche. The palate begins with generous plum & gingernut biscuit, yet leads into edgy minerality & briny undertones. The bright 2011 acidity lends itself to the long, energetic finish, begging for Belon oysters.

2011 was the coolest growing season since 1954, including a greatly truncated Indian summer. The first 15 days of October brought some form of cold and precipitation. October 17-27 saved the day with mostly dry days and one day reached a high of 76. This late in the season, the vines tend to really respond to sun and heat. The wines turned out beautiful, perfumed, and have surprising depth and finish to them. Late season ripening seems to produce wine with leap out of the glass aromatics. This was one of the most challenging vintages ever.

We pressed off the last red wine on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving! Imagine an exhausted, motley, yet grateful harvest crew gathered around the smoked turkey on Thursday. This Thanksgiving was truly something to be grateful for.

COMPOSITION 40% CHARDONNAY – 60% PINOT NOIR
BRIX AT HARVEST:19.5
ALCOHOL: 12.5%
CASES PRODUCED: 13,750
BOTTLE FERMENTED
AGED ON-THE-YEAST
DISGORGED ON DEMAND ®
WINEMAKERS Rollin Soles & Nate Klostermann

MacRostie Chardonnay 2013     on sale     $19.98 
Sonoma Coast, CA
www.dvwinepartners.com
www.macrostiewinery.com

2012 Vintage
92 Pts “Best Buy” & “Year’s Best Chardonnays” Wine & Spirits, April 2014
“This is clean & brisk in lemony acidity, & it offers concentrated, complex flavors of honeyed pineapples, limes, oranges & mangoes. It’s dry & finessed.” - S.H.


“A number of vineyards contribute to the wine, including Sangiacomo at the base of the Sonoma Mountain & Saralee’s in the Russian River Valley. The various sites knit together well, creating an open & fragrant chardonnay redolent of wildflower honey & chanterelle mushrooms. It’s a gentle & harmonious wine that would show well paired with rabbit in a cream sauce”. – L.S. 

90 Pts "Editor's Choice" - Wine Enthusiast, April 2014
“So bright and zingy in acidity, and so ripe in tangerine, mango, lime fruit and honeysuckle, that you hardly notice the oak influence. Yet, it’s there in the form of buttered toast. The result is a big, powerful Chardonnay, clean and vibrant, for drinking now with dramatic shellfish and pork dishes.” - Steve Heimoff

2013 VINTAGE
MacRostie's Sonoma Coast bottling is definitely a top choice for California Chardonnay at this price level. Grapes were sourced from several select Sonoma Coast vineyards including the "A-list" Sangiacomo Vineyard, vineyards belonging to the Dutton and Martinelli estates, and MacRostie's own estate properties. The beautifully ripe & pristine fruit was whole-cluster pressed into 20% new French oak for fermentation where it aged for an additional 6 months. A few lots were fermented in stainless steel to retain some special emphasis on aromatic fruit characteristics. This 2013 bottling has not yet been professionally reviewed, but the similarly styled 2012 vintage garnered 92 points and a "Best Buy" designation from Wines & Spirits.

The wine is pale straw gold in color. Delicate floral aromas introduce this wine followed by lemon citrus and peach stone fruit notes. This wine has a soft entry with an essence of spice from a pie crust and candied orange peel flavors. There is pronounced weight in the mid-palate and finishes with a crisp yet lasting lemon citrus zest on the tongue. 

ORIGIN
The grapes for this Chardonnay came from several excellent vineyards in Sonoma County. Sangiacomo and Champlin Creek vineyards are located in the Carneros region. We work with some amazing Russian River Valley properties as well, including vineyards owned by the well-known Dutton family & Martinelli family. Wildcat Mountain Vineyard, a signature site for MacRostie, is high up in the hills & considered part of the Petaluma Gap region in Sonoma. All of our vineyards are located in unique cool climate areas of the Sonoma Coast appellation & offer distinct and complex characteristics to our Sonoma Coast Chardonnay. 

VINEYARD NOTES 

2013 had ideal temperatures and growing conditions. The fruit came in the door healthy, ripe and luscious. All of the grapes destined for the Sonoma Coast Chardonnay blend were harvested by hand between September 4th and October 9th of 2013. 

VINIFICATION
All grapes went direct to press as whole clusters and then gently pressed. By pressing as whole clusters we can keep the wines delicate and bright. After settling, most of the juice was racked into French oak barrels for fermentation, 20% of which were new. Once the wines completed primary fermentation and a secondary, malo-lactic fermentation, the barrel-fermented lots were aged on the lees for six months, with occasional stirring to increase richness and body. To emphasize fruit aromatics a select few lots were fermented in stainless steel tanks and never went to barrel. The final blend was assembled prior to bottling, which ran the first two weeks of June 2014. This vintage produced about 32,000 (750 ml) cases. MacRostie Winery & Vineyards was founded by winemaker Steve MacRostie in 1987. As a believer in the unique character of Sonoma Coast fruit & an innovative winemaker pioneering a more fresh & sophisticated style of Chardonnay, Steve dedicated himself to crafting wines with an authentic sense of place & championed quality in the region, both in the vineyards & the winery.

Sonoma Coast… Two words that together sum up the wines that Steve MacRostie has been producing since 1987. Sonoma, the town, is his longtime home. Sonoma, the county, may be the most diverse and distinctive wine-growing region in California—a viticultural candy store, where great vineyards growing virtually every renowned variety can be found in abundance. And everyone knows what coast means—sunny, cool, breezy & beautiful. Combine these elements & you have a winemaking paradise. The very first wine that MacRostie made was from a vineyard in the Sonoma Coast region & this area has continued to play a large role in almost every bottling since.

Chardonnay & Pinot Noir show their true potential in the Sonoma Coast, and these are the varieties upon which MacRostie winery focuses its attention. The extended growing season in this marine-influenced climate allows these varieties to mature slowly & completely, developing exceptional depth of flavor that can then be captured in the resulting wines. Long convinced of the region’s greatness, MacRostie planted his estate vineyard, Wildcat Mountain, here in 1998, and this vineyard has since become the jewel in the winery’s crown. MacRostie wines are made in a gentle, natural way, because when the grapes are this good, there’s not much need to intervene. We let our vineyards speak for themselves.

MacRostie’s winery operation is Certified by the California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance (CSWA), a nonprofit organization created by the Wine Institute and the California Association of Winegrape Growers. In addition, MacRostie is certified as a California Green Business — a government program that recognizes & assists businesses that operate in an environmentally friendly manner. “Our efforts to conserve water, energy, and other resources are in line with keeping Sonoma the beautiful natural place it is today.” Steve MacRostie

The team at MacRostie Winery has been working towards decreasing our energy and water usage. Since 2005 we have decreased our water usage by 29% percent & our energy usage by 2%. In 2012 we received certification from California Sustainable Winegrowing Alliance (CSWA).

Argyle Nuthouse Chardonnay 2010     on sale     $23.98 
Willamette Valley, Oregon
www.dvwinepartners.com
www.argylewinery.com 

The 2010 Nuthouse Chardonnay embodies an old-world elegance. It pulls you in with complexity and nuance, with a nose of toasted hazelnuts, rock melon & flinty gunpowder notes. The nose doesn’t quite prepare the drinker for the bright crispness of the palate, refreshing & clean. Flavors of quince, lemon custard, and a zest of minerality akin to wet limestone holds the acidity on the finish of the palate. It’s this cool-climate acidity that makes this wine a perfect companion at the dinner table. While fresh & enticing now, this wine promises to build mid-palate richness with time in the bottle to yield a truly sublime experience. 

The season started out unusually cool, delaying grape flowering until well into July. Even then, the weather was not great and poor pollination produced smaller than average clusters. Even then we were compelled to remove grape clusters to get the yields well below average. There is just not enough growing season left to ripen a normal crop. A season saving string of 80+ degree days at the end of September gave us all hope of ripening and put life back into our plans to make red wine. A bit of warm, soaking rain in early October sent us into further removing leaves and working to keep fruit healthy. Mid-October brought an great, dry forecast and harvest began with a bang to beat predicted October 23rd rains. Red wine was harvested with gusto beginning the 17th and we wrapped up harvest the 21st October. Keys to our success were, small crop, healthy fruit, and patience to wait until the very end of the season to pick. 

Wine Production Stats
Varietal: 100% Oregon Chardonnay, Dijon clone; Vineyard: Lone Star AVA: Eola-Amity Hills; Alcohol: 13.0%;
Cases Produced: 916; Winemakers: Rollin Soles and Andrew Davis

Argyle Pinot Noir 2013     on sale     $22.98
Willamette Valley, Oregon
www.dvwinepartners.com
www.argylewinery.com 

2012 Vintage:
90 Pts – Wine Spectator
"Lithe, with a nice transparency to the polished texture & the tea leaf-accented cherry & herb flavors, sliding easily into a graceful finish. Drink now through 2017. 26,685 cases made." –HS

Previous Vintages:
2011: Wine Spectator 90
2010: Wine Spectator 90
2009: Wine Spectator 89
2008: Wine Advocate 90
2008: Wine Spectator 90

Argyle Pinot Noir is 100% Argyle-grown. Willamette Valley Pinot Noir is a stunning showcase of classic, cool-climate varietal character: black berry, black cherry, spicy complexity folds nicely into fresh earth on the middle palate.

Argyle Pinot Noir is an honest representation of the Willamette Valley. Fermented entirely in small lots, and blended for purity, 2013 toes the line between red and dark cherry, while offering spicy forest floor and hints of black tea. The palate is lively and graceful, building density and focus as the silky tannins build into the long, energetic finish.

The majority of the 2013 growing season was pretty normal in terms of weather, much like 2012, when La Niña faded & customary conditions returned. Bud break and bloom timing were on the mark, indicating an early October Pinot Noir harvest. Towards the end of September, just after our sparkling harvest, the forecast seemed more ominous and hardly believable. Argyle’s experience and maturity paid big dividends against such a backdrop. As the certainty of the forecast increased, we went to the whip at low elevations, particularly our Lone Star Vineyard. After the initial blitzkrieg, we hunkered down and received 6 inches of rain in a weekend. We caught our breath and waited, almost a full week. Following the rain there was another flurry of action, as we went to work dropping any compromised fruit. Yields were certainly diminished but as the end of September blew over, we were blessed with a dry, sunny October. This late-game break in the weather allowed our high elevation grapes to dry out and ripen into a small, but gorgeous crop.

COMPOSITION: 100% PINOT NOIR
BRIX AT HARVEST: 22 - 23
ALCOHOL 13.0%
CASES PRODUCED: 35,000
WINEMAKER Nate Klostermann


MacRostie Pinot Noir 2012     on sale     $25.98

Sonoma Coast, CA
www.dvwinepartners.com
www.macrostiewinery.com
2012 Vintage
90 Pts – Wine Review Online
MacRostie’s Sonoma Coast Pinot Noir is one of the best values in California Pinot today. It is made in a lean style, with firm tannins that hide much of the fruit at this stage, but lurking in the background there is plenty of strawberry, raspberry, cherry fruit aroma ready to surface as the tannins soften. If you hold this wine another year or two before opening, you may well be pleasantly amazed. — Robert Whitley, Jan. 6, 2015

90 Pts – Wine Review Online
Rich black cherry and raspberry fruit are complimented with cinnamon, talc, mild dry earth and touches of mushroom make up aroma and flavor profiles in this nicely priced Sonoma Coast offering. Structured acidity and a long finish that shows a bit of damp earth suggests pairing with roasted meats with tarragon, rosemary and sage. — Rich Cook, Dec. 16, 2014

89 Points – Wine Advocate
The 2012 Pinot Noir Sonoma Coast offers plum, cherry & berry fruit intermixed with earth & flower characteristics. This medium-bodied, seductive Pinot has no hard edges, so enjoy it over the next 3-4 years. — Dec. 2014

2011 Vintage
91 Pts – Smart Buy – The Pinot Report
“Medium ruby color; light spice and cherry aromas; ripe, cherry and spice flavors with some earthy notes; silky texture; good structure and balance; long finish. Spicy, pretty flavors make this a great Pinot for the table.”

2010 Vintage
91 Pts – Editors’ Choice – Wine Enthusiast
“Deep, brooding aromas of forest floor mark this dramatic Pinot. It suggests wild, woodland raspberries, pine needles, balsam, cola and earthy mushrooms. Dry and modest in alcohol, it’s a skillful interpretation of a difficult, cool vintage. Nice to drink now, and will age for at least six years.” —S.H.

2009 Vintage
92 Pts – Wine Enthusiast
“…a smooth, silky Pinot Noir… ripe in flavors of cherry-pie filling & spice, with fine acidity & gentle tannins. With grapes from four vineyards, it shows a mastery of the art of blending.”

2012 Vintage
This wine is rich cranberry in color. Lively red raspberry and soft cinnamon spice form the aroma. This vintage shows firm acidity with a slight mushroom note in the palate that leads into a lasting finish. This vintage produced 4174 (9L) cases 

WINEMAKING NOTES
All of the grapes were de-stemmed into open-top fermenters using our gentle de-stemmer. Following a three-day cold soak to boost color without increasing tannins, the tanks were inoculated with yeast. The caps were managed with a combination of punchdowns and pumpovers to maximize positive extraction, and the must was gently pressed when dry. The resulting wines were aged in French oak barrels, 30% of which were new, for ten months, with a single gentle racking under inert gas to assemble the blend in late March. Bottling then took place on August 9th, 2013. 

VINEYARD NOTES
Approaching harvest it was noted that the 2012 growing season was a beauty. Prior to October 1st, there had not been a day over 100 degrees in our region, making for an ideal, evenly paced growing season. Then the weather warmed up which ushered all of our remaining grapes to optimal ripeness. Neither rain nor the threat of rain were ever factors which ensured ideal picking decisions. The grapes that went into this blend were harvested by hand between mid-September & mid-October of 2012. 

ORIGIN
The grapes for this Pinot Noir came from vineyards in the cool Sonoma Coast AVA, including Champlin Creek and Wildcat Mountain in Petaluma Gap, Hellenthal Vineyard in Fort Ross-Seaview and Dutton-Hallberg Ranch in the Russian River Valley. 50% of the fruit for this wine comes from Russian River Valley vineyards. As a result, this wine is very fruit driven and elegant.

Fidelity Merlot – Cab Sauv Meritage 2013   on sale  $12.98    

Alexander Valley, California 

Lauber SKU[masked]     

http://visionwinebrands.com/fidelity 

www.goldschmidtvineyards.com 

Fidelity is a Bordeaux-styled red from the Alexander Valley, Nick Goldschmidt's only blended wine that he produces.  Full-bodied & smooth, Fidelity shows strawberry & black cherry flavors and a soft, supple finish. The French oak adds extra dimensional to this very pleasing wine.

The grapes for this Meritage blend are sourced from the Crazy Creek Estate in Alexander Valley. Crazy Creek is known for low vigor, with an Eastern exposure & loamy soils. Crazy Creek is one of Nick Goldschmidt’s favorite vineyard sites & consistently produces juicy, very flavorful Merlot. This amazing value is a blend of 87% Merlot, 11% Cabernet Sauvignon, 2% Petit Verdot. 

Alcohol: 14.3%

PIONEERING VITICULTURE
Argyle Winery was established in Dundee, Oregon in the Willamette Valley in 1987. Argyle is "Grower First", focusing our attention at the source – continually improving viticulture on over 650 hillside acres sited on the very best vineyard locations in Oregon's Willamette Valley. Argyle's commitment to improvement, at the vineyards and at the winery, has been built on a bedrock of innovation and practices that are L.I.V.E. Certified Sustainable *** & Oregon Certified Sustainable.

• Argyle is recognized as having been at the forefront of Oregon’s viticultural revolution.
• Argyle is a New World pioneer in high density vines grown on de-vigorating rootstock.
• Argyle is the first Oregon winery to use Dijon Clone Chardonnay and Pinot Noir for 'Grower' Sparkling wine.

Argyle’s Footprint - WILLAMETTE VALLEY, OREGON
¬The Willamette Valley is 150 miles long and up to 60 miles wide making it Oregon's largest AVA with the greatest concentration of vineyards located in new sub-appellations - A.V.A.’s. These new AVA’s recognize that the best vineyard sites are located on
hillside slopes within the rain shadow of the Coast Range Mountains:
Dundee Hills, Eola-Amity Hills, McMinnville, Ribbon Ridge, Yamhill Carlton District and Chehalem Mountain.
¬ The Willamette Valley, with cool, wet winters and warm, dry summers, is characterized by a temperate marine climate that provides gentle growing conditions ideal for cool climate Chardonnay, Riesling and Pinot Noir.

Vineyard soils are derived from volcanic basalt and sedimentary seabed sandstone & shale. Elevation plays an essential role from our vantage point North of the 45th Parallel. This cool climate region is also famous for its agricultural diversity, growing everything from hazelnuts to hops, berries & cherries.

*** L.I.V.E. (LOW INPUT VITICULTURE AND ENOLOGY)
L.I.V.E. is an Oregon agricultural sustainability organization that certifies vineyards and wineries adhere to sustainable practices that are in accord with international standards. L.I.V.E.’s certification process, which balances the needs of worker, consumer and environmental health along with economic sustainability, is the result of an ongoing dialogue between academics, growers and environmentalists. Argyle Winery & Vineyards are among Oregon’s first to be declared “L.I.V.E. Certified Sustainable”.

Over the last 25 years, Argyle has demonstrated that it can actually improve grape quality & still ensure the health of its workers, its community, its vines and the land.

Winemaker - Rollin Soles
Winemaker and founder, Rollin Soles, has produced wines that have garnered high praise & fond attention from wine critics & enthusiasts for more than 25 years. Throughout the years Rollin has continued to produce wines that are ranked among the Top 100 Wines of the World by the Wine Spectator (more times than any other Oregon winery). Rollin approaches winemaking with a personal passion & dedication and has helped reinvent the Oregon wine industry by increasing the quality of Oregon’s vineyards & winemaking.

ARGYLE’S HISTORY – Willamette Valley Pioneers
In the early 80’s, Rollin Soles and Brian Croser came together on a common vision of prospecting the New World’s coolest latitudes for wine production. In 1987, they staked a claim in Oregon’s Willamette Valley, a place ideal for late season ripened Pinot Noir and Chardonnay. Argyle Winery is a Grower First, producing world-class Methodé Champenoise Sparkling wine, barrel fermented Chardonnay and silky textured Pinot Noir from low yielding vines on Argyle-farmed hillside slopes.


A TALE OF TWO HOUSES…
THE SPIRITHOUSE STORY
Argyle’s Victorian farmhouse tasting room was dubbed “ The Spirithouse” in tribute to the ghost of an early 1900’s Dundee pioneer woman said to roam the halls. Argyle Winemaker Rollin Soles reports a few otherwise unexplained occurrences & noises that have ‘gone bump in the night’ but adds the ghost is a good spirit! Spirithouse Pinot Noir & Spirithouse Chardonnay honor the friendly ghost.

THE NUTHOUSE STORY
The Willamette Valley is also famous for its hazelnuts (Filberts, that is, if you want to fit in with the locals!) Argyle built its modern winery facility on what was originally a hazelnut processing plant. As a tribute to its history, Argyle established the limited production - “Nuthouse” Chardonnay & Pinot Noir in keeping with our “squirrel friendly” heritage.

Founded in 1987 by Sonoma County winemaking pioneer & Chardonnay & Pinot Noir specialist, Steve MacRostie, MacRostie Winery & Vineyards has established itself as one of the Sonoma Coast’s defining wineries & a leader in a bright, balanced & age-worthy style of Chardonnay & Pinot Noir. Using grapes farmed by legendary winegrowing families, including the Duttons, Sangiacomos, Martinellis & Bacigalupis, & from Steve’s own Wildcat Mountain Vineyard in the mountainous Petaluma Gap region, MacRostie has assembled one of the Sonoma Coast’s most acclaimed & diverse vineyard programs.

Steve MacRostie, Founder
Since beginning his winemaking career 37 years ago, Steve MacRostie has developed a reputation as one of California’s most respected veteran winemakers. At the same time he has helped to pioneer the use of fruit from both Carneros and the Sonoma Coast. As the founder and original winemaker for MacRostie Winery and Vineyards, Steve has earned wide acclaim for crafting balanced wines, with an emphasis on Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. 

A native Californian, Steve was born in Pasadena and raised in Sacramento. In the process of preparing for medical school, he earned a degree in biology from Washington’s Whitman College in 1968. Following his time at Whitman, Steve served in the U.S. Army, which trained him as a cryptographer and deployed him to Vicenza in the Veneto region of Italy. While in Europe, Steve took advantage of the opportunity to travel to France, Germany and Spain. European wines were an epiphany for him – far surpassing the few American wines he had tasted – and he quickly fell in love with wine, and the idea of winemaking. 

Following the adventurous spirit that would inform many future decisions, Steve soon abandoned the idea of a career in medicine, and instead enrolled in the enology program at the University of California, Davis. Upon graduation in 1974, Steve joined Sonoma County’s Hacienda Winery as its inaugural winemaker. While at Hacienda, Steve refined his skills, quickly gaining renown as a winemaker capable of crafting benchmark Chardonnays and age-worthy Pinot Noirs. At the same time, he began greatly appreciating the fruit he was working with from a few exceptional small vineyards—all located in an area that would later gain appellation status as Carneros. 

After 12 years with Hacienda, Steve felt that he had enough experience to put his own name on a wine. In 1987, with the support of his wife Thale, Steve founded MacRostie Winery and Vineyards. As a winemaker, Steve focused on Carneros grapes to craft fresh and elegant cool-climate wines—at the time, an innovative approach. While pioneering this more sophisticated style, Steve continued building relationships with top growers throughout the region that have lasted for decades. 

In 1997, Steve made another pivotal decision with the establishment of his Wildcat Mountain Vineyard on the borderlands of Carneros and the Sonoma Coast. This partnership with ranchers Nancy and Tony Lilly has solidified Steve’s reputation as a winemaking and viticultural leader in both Carneros and the Sonoma Coast. While Steve is still active in every facet of MacRostie Winery and Vineyards, including the blending process, he now focuses his considerable energies on the development of Wildcat Mountain Vineyard, while also acting as vineyard liaison with the winery’s coveted portfolio of growers. In 2004, Steve handpicked Kevin Holt as MacRostie’s winemaker. 

A longtime advocate on behalf of Sonoma County, and Sonoma Valley (where he lives), Steve has served as president of the Sonoma Valley Vintners and Growers Alliance, the Carneros Wine Alliance and the Carneros Quality Alliance.


Heidi Bridenhagen, Winemaker
An up-and-coming superstar of the wine industry, Heidi has seven years of winemaking experience including harvests at California’s Kendall Jackson and Clos du Bois and New Zealand’s Oyster Bay (Delegate’s Wine Estates). Heidi’s former position as Enologist at the famed SonomaCutrer Winery provided the foundation for her strong passion for the region and Chardonnay and Pinot Noir winemaking. “These two varietals show their true potential in the Sonoma Coast. The extended growing season in this marine influenced climate allows these varieties to mature slowly and completely, developing exceptional depth of flavor that can then be captured in our MacRostie wines.” 

Heidi brings this passion to MacRostie and has focused on building a small portfolio of partner growers during her two years as Enologist and Winemaker. “Our partnerships with these iconic small vineyards, who are committed to sustainable farming methods, contribute to the success and quality of our Sonoma Coast blends.” 

Heidi has intimate knowledge of each individual lot and the various layers they contribute to the wine. “When I taste MacRostie’s Sonoma Coast Chardonnay, I get a mineral edge from vineyards in the far west, floral and lemon notes from vineyards on the valley floor, and a phenolic complexity from our foggy, windy estate Wildcat Mountain Vineyard on the south-western corner of Carneros” 

Heidi has a very “hands-on” approach in the cellar and out in the vineyards, from sustainability projects to lab analysis, blending and bottling. Heidi is involved in all facets of winemaking to ensure the highest quality fruit, optimal harvest time and crafting award-winning, unique wines expressive of Sonoma Coast. 

A native of Door County, WI, Heidi has a Bachelor of Arts in Biochemistry from the University of Colorado at Boulder. In addition to travel (including an eight month stint in Europe) Heidi enjoys tee time, winter sports, experimenting in the kitchen with new recipes and wine pairings, and hitting up local breweries for craft beer tasting.

Born & educated in New Zealand, Nick Goldschmidt’s career began in 1982 with a research position at the New Zealand Lincoln University where he graduated with Distinction in Horticulture. Nick went on to specialize in viticulture studies at Wagga Wagga, and oenology at the highly acclaimed Roseworthy program, at Adelaide University in South Australia. During his time as a student Nick worked at noted wineries such as Kumeu River, Coopers Creek & Babich. In 1989, after 18 months of winemaking in Australia, New Zealand, California & South America; including his first harvest in Chile as winemaker for Calitera, Nick returned to California with an amazing range of winemaking experiences.

In 1990, Nick and his wife Yolyn settled down in Healdsburg, California, as Simi's Associate Winemaker. Nick was promoted to Chief Winemaker 1991 and became Vice President & Chief Winemaker in 1996. Nick spent a total of 13 years at Simi and was one of the driving forces that brought the Simi Reserve Cabernet program to notoriety. In May of 2003 Nick accepted the position of Executive Vice President & Winemaker at Allied Domecq Wines USA and was subsequently named Vice President and Executive Domestic Winemaker for Beam Estates wine portfolio.

Yolyn & Nick Goldschmidt are owner/vintners & Nick is the winemaker. The winery offices are located in Healdsburg. Both originally from New Zealand, Yolyn & Nick have spent time living & working in the wine areas of New Zealand, Australia & South America.

Goldschmidt Vineyards is a vehicle by which Nick & Yolyn present their innovative way of wine making & wine presentation. There are two brands under their portfolio - the prestigious Goldschmidt Vineyard Cabernet Sauvignon label & the international Forefathers label. The Goldschmidt wine program is designed to showcase single vineyard source wines from both the Alexander Valley and Napa Valley Oakville appellations. The goal is to create wines that highlight the distinct characters, benefits and attributes derived from these site specific harvests.

The Goldschmidt Vineyard label is a program designed to showcase single vineyard source wines from both the Alexander Valley and Napa Valley Oakville appellations. The goal is create wines that highlight the distinct characters, benefits and attributes derived from these site specific harvests. Goldschmidt Vineyards Cabernets are crafted with the best possible resources to achieve exceptional richness, quality and balance – the hallmarks of world-class wines.

Joined periodically in the field by their five children, the Goldschmidt expertise is being passed down to the next generation, as evidenced in the wines released under the labels Chelsea Goldschmidt, Hilary Goldschmidt and Katherine Goldschmidt.         

Some Goldschmidt Vineyards grapes...

results.description:
Cold Season Formulas- To MaHuang or not to MaHuang, that is the Question

                                               With Nigel Dawes M.A. L.Ac.


With bitter weather around the corner, we examine an overview of cold season formulas and their proper applications. With cold season pathogens, it is key to make an accurate diagnosis and proper formula choice for complete resolution and to avoid damage due to treatment. In this lecture, Nigel Dawes will profile traditional cold season formulas and their application, help us understand clinical presentation of cold pathogens, and will finally answer the burning question- to MaHuang or not to MaHuang?

Nigel Dawes has been practicing and teaching Oriental Medicine for more than 25 years. He lived and studied in Japan for 5 years followed by hospital internships in China . Prior to moving to the United States he founded and directed the London College of Shiatsu , and began lecturing at various Oriental Medicine (OM) schools in England, France, Israel and the U.S. Since 1994 New York City has been his home, where he has continued his involvement in undergraduate and graduate OM education and administration, political work in the field, clinical practice, and publishing.


These days Nigel divides his time between clinical practice, teaching, and publication & research. He is currently considered one of the leading experts in the practice and teaching of Kampo , lecturing widely throughout the US and abroad and recently publishing a translation of a modern Japanese Kampo classic. In New York, he is on the faculty of both Tristate College of Acpuncture and Pacific College of Oriental Medicine where he teaches both Kampo and Japanese Acupuncture courses and supervises in clinic.
Nigel's Oriental Medicine clinic is located in New York City and incorporates Acupuncture, Shiatsu and Kampo herbal medicine. He lives in Brooklyn with his wife and two children.

This meetup will be in a 90 minute lecture format

Attendees will be given a coupon of $20.00 toward purchases at Kamwo's E-Script Online Store; however you must be present in order to redeem coupon.
results.name: Cold Season Formulas: To MaHuang or not to MaHuang, with Nigel Dawes

results.description:
Join us for Summer Tennis.

Check in at Clubhouse for court assignment upon arrival, then play under the lights 'til 10:00pm at this beautiful wooded park*.

Please remember to check in with the clubhouse to reserve a court. Players need to reserve a court with at least one other player present and should be a Hudson County resident with ID.

Mention to the court staff that you are with the Meetup group and ask that they keep us together if possible (3 courts).

Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game. And remember to bring plenty of water!

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending. I will provide my cell # for RSVP's so we can find each other. Please also bear in mind that we are usually on more than one court - they are available on a first-come, first-serve basis. You should locate other players and grab a court when you arrive.

Although we won't enforce attendance, please keep your rsvp updated because others are looking to find partners to hit with. Remove your name from the list if you are not planning to attend.

Inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

Thank you all for this great group!

*Free for Hudson County residents. Those outside of Hudson County may play as a guest of the resident players to avoid a possible $10 fee to play.
results.name: Wednesday Evening Tennis at Lincoln Park

results.description: Do you need some capital for your business? Have you been trying to launch a new product, build a website, lease an office, set up an effective marketing campaign? If banks have turned you down you still have options. Please join us for a special conversation on how to get a business loan from lending companies, what the requirements are and the overview of the application process. You can get your projects done sooner and build credit for your business. Presenters: Daniel Delgado has extensive experience providing financial assistance and education to entrepreneurs. Currently, Daniel holds a counselor position at Accion East (http://www.accioneast.org), where he is engaged in all stages of application and decision-making process of the small business financing. Daniel is also an author and developer of multiple workshops which help entrepreneurs to manage financial side of business development. Daniel holds a BA in Economics and an MS in Business Finance, fluent in English and Spanish. Accion East is a nonprofit microfinance organization that helps small businesses with access to capital and financial education. Accion East has provided over $132 million in over 20,000 microloans since its inception in 1991, helping small businesses to grow and strengthen the communities they serve. Learn more at http://www.accioneast.org Please register at http://www.meetup.com/Startups-Entrepreneurs-Legal-Group/events/226351829/
results.name: How to Get Cash For Your Projects

results.description:
With the evolution of communication technologies over the last few decades, there has also been a drastic increase in fraud in the banking industry. According to Javelin Strategy & Research, $16 billion was stolen from 12.7 million identity fraud victims in 2014. Banks have long employed statistical models to fight fraud, but with the exponential increase in fraudulent activities, banks now need scalable and automated technology solutions to combat it.

In this talk, we’ll walk through two distinct use cases. We will explore the model for fraud detection at Integral Ad Science. We will also discuss how banks are using successfully Hadoop ecosystem technologies like Apache Kafka, Apache HBase, and Apache Spark (among others) to handle fraud detection across multiple channels. This discussion will cover batch and streaming architectures with a focus on the financial services, but the concepts will be applicable across industries.

Presenters: Alexey Kharlamov & Jeff Shmain

Alexey is a VP of Technology at Integral Ad Science. He has 15+ years designing and implementing high-performance and data intensive applications using solutions including Hadoop, NoSQL and Java to name a few. He has built custom solutions for eCommerce, advertising and financial services. 

Jeff is a Senior Solution Architect at Cloudera. He has 16+ years of financial industry experience with strong focus on security trading, risk, and regulations. Over the last few years, he has worked on various use case implementations at 8 of the 10 world's largest investment banks.
results.name: Design Patterns for Real-Time Fraud Detection on Hadoop

results.description:
Join us for a night ride into Citi Bike's improved data streams, get a sneak preview of their beta app team, and meet their chief geeks!

As part of our transportation series, we will have representatives of Citi Bike's data team talking about system improvements, data improvements, and how you can plug into Citi Bike's digital future. 

Join us for a discussion about system data, operations, and tools. Come with your questions and insights on how we can use and improve NYC bike data feeds. 

Are you working with Citibike data? Represent your project at our Nov 18th BetaTalk!

If you are currently working with Citibike data, please post about your project on our discussion board at talk.beta.nyc.

Relevant links:

• Citi Bike data


• BikeNYC & Citi Bike NYC hackers email list 

-=-=-

Agenda:

7:00 - Doors open with networking
7:30 - Event starts with introductions 
7:45 - Citibike takes the handle bars
8:45 - Presentations are docked
9:00 - Event ends and cleanup 

-=-=-

Event Partners:

The Code for America Brigade program is an international network of people committed to using their voices and hands, in collaboration with local governments, to make their cities better.

Microsoft Civic aims to collaboratively address the most pressing community challenges through the hyper-local creation, deployment, and evangelism of civic technology.

Accela provides civic engagement solutions for government. Accela’s solutions uniquely address the diverse needs of their constituents by making publicly available information more accessible. The Accela Civic Platform includes solutions for land management, asset management, licensing and case management, legislative management, right of way management, citizen relationship management, recreation and resource management, environmental health and safety.

-=-=-

Note about the venue:

You should RSVP with the name that appears on a photo ID. In order to give building security an RSVP list, RSVPs will close at 4:00 PM the day of the event. If you miss this deadline, most of the time security is nice and will let you in.

BetaNYC is committed to hosting safe and open events for all. By attending this event you are committing yourself to BetaNYC's Code of Conduct and Anti-Harassment Policy.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the second floor, in the coworking space.

results.description:
*** To secure your spot, please make sure to register on Eventbrite! 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/igda-nyc-wigi-nyc-women-in-games-roundtable-tickets-19476894917 ***

52% of gamers are women, according to a study by the Internet Advertising Bureau. However, games and the game industry often present an entirely different picture. The International Game Developers Association (IGDA) NYC and Women in Games International (WIGI) NYC are teaming up to present a roundtable discussion about the experience of being a woman in games, both as a player and as a creator.


We’ll discuss topics such as:

-How are women currently treated in the games space, as creators and players?

-How can we make the games space better and more inclusive?

-How can we support women creators, and provide education for new female developers?

-Anything else that comes to mind!


The event will be moderated by Maria Saint Martin, co-founder of the WIGI NYC chapter, and feature a panel of local game developers, educators, advocates, and players.


Afterwards, we’ll open it up to the crowd and the bulk of the evening will be dedicated to a participatory roundtable discussion among peers.


Game creators of all genders and disciplines are welcome! Capacity will be strictly limited, so make sure to reserve your seat on Eventbrite. Have a burning question, a brilliant solution, a sticky situation, or an issue you’ve been wrestling with? Come talk shop with other game devs, share knowledge, and gain insight.

About the moderator:


Maria Saint Martin


Maria is a game designer and visual artist who has always been fascinated in exploring how games can make us reflect on who we are and how we interact with the world around us. She has a Masters in Game Design from NYU, and her thesis project, an online asymmetrical multiplayer horror game, “The Curse of Mannequin Island” was shown at the Tokyo Game Show. Her experience ranges from game design to illustration and art direction. She’s originally from Mexico City where she worked on multiple mobile games including a Hot Wheels mobile game. She also worked at Walt Disney World in the art department of Creative Entertainment where she learned to love physical design. Most recently she worked as a game designer at Turbo Studios. She is co-founder of Women in Games International NYC Chapter, which focuses on democratizing knowledge, opening the space for conversation and creating an inclusive community.

About the panelists:


Jane Friedhoff


Jane Friedhoff is a riot grrrl game designer and creative technologist who loves exploring how games can create new, unusual, and surprising relationships between people  She co-founded the Code Liberation Foundation, which provides free, trans-inclusive, women-only game design and programming classes. She graduated with her MFA in Design and Technology from Parsons in 2013. Her portfolio includes Slam City Oracles, 2nd Amendment, and Scream 'Em Up. Her games and interactive pieces has been shown at a wide variety of events, including Babycastles, NYU's No Quarter, Different Games, Come Out and Play, Indiecade, GDC, and E3, and her academic work has been published in DiGRA. If a project involves screaming, awkwardness, or dance parties, she’s probably into it.


Margaret Robertson


Margaret is a game director at Play Dots, the makers of two Dots, leading development on new game projects. In her previous role as President of Hide&Seek New York, Margaret made big games (like the city-wide 12,000 player New Year Games), small games (like the Tiny Games project), silly games (like Drunk Dungeon) and serious games (like Dreams Of Your Life). Her earlier work as an independent consultant enabled her to contribute to a huge range of projects, from AAA console titles, through download and mobile/ handheld games, to indie and art-house projects. She's worked with brands, broadcasters, and film studios to develop their game strategies, and was part of the team that built the Channel 4‘s BAFTA- and Emmy-award winning educational game slate. Previously editor-in-chief of Edge magazine, and a co-chair of Indiecade East, she is an internationally top-rated speaker on game design theory.


Asia Hoe


Asia is a Product Designer at 2U, a company that designs experiences for advanced online degrees at world class universities. Raised in a family of gamers, Asia has been an avid gamer since the age of 2. Games have been the genesis for most of her interests and hobbies including art, design, and code. She enjoys streaming on Twitch and studying game design and development. Collaborating with friends at Brooklyn Gamery at the Global Game Jam in 2014, she helped design Five Stages, a game about breakups through the lens of the 5 stages of grief. A regular volunteer with Code Liberation and Games 4 Change, Asia is passionate about bringing the joy of games to all.


Cindy Chow


Cindy was born and raised in beautiful Vancouver, Canada during the great video game resurgence of the mid-80's, and lives and breathes gaming. Having extensive volunteer experience at the prestigious Vancouver Film School, as well as being a pivotal member of Canada's Women in Games Chapter, Cindy recently co-founded New York's own WIGI Chapter to promote awareness and inclusion in the gaming community. Career-wise, Cindy has held administrative positions at Blue Castle, Capcom and Slant Six before moving Vancouver's East Side Games where she found her true passion, working in Community Management. She recently moved to New York to be the Community Manager at TURBO Studios. When not running Nightfall Strikes in Destiny or cooking up Mirelurk steaks in Fallout 4, Cindy can be found consuming a Shack Burger with cheese fries while trying to beat her forever increasing Threes score.

results.description:
At the heart of The Husband’s Secret is a letter that is not meant to be read...

My darling Cecilia,
If you’re reading this, then I’ve died...

Imagine your husband wrote you a letter, to be opened after his death. Imagine, too, that the letter contains his deepest, darkest secret—something with the potential to destroy not only the life you have built together, but the lives of others as well. And then imagine that you stumble across that letter while your husband is still very much alive…

Cecilia Fitzpatrick has achieved it all—she’s an incredibly successful businesswoman, a pillar of her small community, a devoted wife and mother. Her life is as orderly and spotless as her home. But that letter is about to change everything—and not just for her. There are other women who barely know Cecilia—or each other—but they, too, are about to feel the earth-shattering repercussions of her husband’s secret.
results.name: Bayonne Book Club Meetup - The Husband's Secret by Liane Moriarty

results.description:
D&D Encounters is an episodic-format event designed to allow new players to join in and learn D&D in a casual, pick-up game. Seasoned players with erratic schedules can easily hop in and out of Encounters; unlike a traditional campaign, DMs and players will rotate, resulting in a dynamic game experience. We are using the latest edition of D&D (5e) and each session lasts about 3-4 hours, easily fitting into your work or school schedule, and presents a new and exciting challenge each week. The $10 fee covers your use of the playspace, though committing to 10 weeks grants the player a discount.


We're always on the lookout for DM talent for this season-- volunteers keep programs like this one alive! However, more important than veteran DMs, Encounters is a place where even new players should feel comfortable testing out the DMing waters. Every Saturday we provide our DMs with that week's "adventure chunk", a set of 2-3 encounters in one simple, easy-to-read packet. This bite-sized DMing format is ideal for new DMs and veterans who don't have the time to create an entire campaign from scratch, and allow lots of room for alterations and improvisations as the DM sees fit. DMs who volunteer their time do not pay the $10 fee, and receive a steep discount on our D&D related products.


For our first session, we will be creating level 1 characters and running a brief "test run" of our new adventurers as they get their footing the world of the Forgotten Realms. It won't be long before we're on the road to great deeds, so you won't want to miss this great opportunity to get to know your fellow heroes!

Please private message Timm with any questions regarding DMing, the event, or anything else RPG related!
results.name: Brooklyn Strategist Presents: D&D Encounters, Rage of Demons

The TV-B-Gone - A universal remote that turns off any television. ANY TV. Reduce distractions at the bar, cause havoc at Best Buy, and feel like a superhero. Exclusive MakerBar Swag Edition developed by members! - $30 - 2 Hours - Medium Difficulty

If our relationship to time is stressed, our relationship to life is stressed. The “busy” syndrome that so many of us own in our day-to-day keeps us away from experiencing and living the moment we are actually in. My discussion will be hallmarked by a look at what makes us so busy and how we can better manage our time, unclutter our lives and feel less overwhelmed. The interactive activity and the coloring circle will emphasize the power of living with a “today” mentality, focusing on the process of creating small, actionable steps toward positive action.

This session is different. 

We actually are meeting in the chapel! This is not a religious season but a regular figure drawing session in an amazing setting. 

We will have a nude model posing as usual, it will just be in a chapel!

You're invited to join us for this weekly opportunity to sharpen your drawing skills! This session is open to sketchers of all levels.

What makes our sessions different? 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.


• We have coffee and cookies at the long break. 

• We finish on time so you can be headed home at 9:00 p.m sharp! 

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)

• This is a two hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  

• We start with short 2 minute poses and work up to a 20 minute pose by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 


• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
Are you trying to break into the tech field? Curious about what its like to work in different technical positions? Looking to hire members for your team? Join us for the GDI Careers speaker series “A Day in the Life” and learn more about important pieces of a tech team. Hear from a panel of ladies from different companies and at different points in their career about how they came to be a professional in the tech industry, what their day-to-day responsibilities are like, and what advice they have for folks looking to enter the field.

Schedule for the evening:

7:00 - 7:15 Snacks and GDI Intro

7:15 - 8:00 Panelist Perspectives

8:00 - 8:30 Moderated and Open Q&A

8:30 - 9:00 Networking

Employers and recruiters are welcome to attend and bring marketing materials to share with attendees following the panel! Please note that you will be attending when you RSVP so that you can be announced.

A $10 donation toward the Girl Develop It scholarship fund is requested to confirm your attendance. 

Learn more about the panelists: 


Lindsay Neubauer started programming in high school when she was convinced to take AP Java because it didn't require homework. Nine years later, she loves Java but has expanded her programming language tool belt to include C++, Javascript, PHP, and Python. She has worked in academic research, experimenting with code clones at the Java byte-code level as well as forensic comparison of document similarity. Since finishing her masters at Columbia, she has been working as a software engineer at Sailthru. When she is not working hard improving Sailthru's product, Lindsay spends time walking her dog and volunteer teaching AP Java at a high school in Union Square through a program called TEALS.

Amy Gimma is a nurse turned developer at Epion Health, where she is working to improve the way healthcare information is collected and communicated. She learned to program through online resources, books, and on the job training, which gives her an understanding of what it's like to learn to code for someone new to the tech industry. She is interested in using programming to solve social and practical problems, and teaching people of all different backgrounds to code.erent backgrounds to code. 

Brenda Storer is a front-end developer and designer based in New York City, which has been her home for 10 years. She was born and raised in the Silicon Valley and has also lived in London and Italy, but she currently codes for the Thoughtbot, and teaches women how to code for GDI.


Corey Nilan worked as a speech-language pathologist until she discovered programming and the world of web development, and she never looked back. She loves Ruby and Rails, but JavaScript is making in-roads into her heart. Corey is a web developer for Refinery29. She also teaches with Girl Develop It and coaches at Dev Bootcamp and loves being able to help other students with their own coding journey.

Steph Zhang is a developer at BuzzFeed.
results.name: GDI NYC Careers | A Day in the Life | Developer & Technologist

results.description:
PLEASE SIGN UP THROUGH EVENTBRITE

About the Presentation: 

Most people have a few favorite restaurants, places to go when we want to be treated like a close friend or family member, enjoy the company we’re with, and eat well. For special occasions, or just for variety, sometimes we will try a new place to dine. These new experiences often delight, and it’s as if we’ve made a new friend, but other times we are turned off by the food or service, never to return. 

We'll explore how we can apply the key concepts from a great restaurant experience to the user experiences we design - and learn the lessons from those who fail to meet their customers' needs. We'll connect these ideas to what we know about how the human brain works and how our emotions impact our decision making, and discover what great restaurateurs and great digital designers do in common.

About the Presenter: 

Jimmy Chandler, an independent UX Architect, works with enterprises, startups, and non-profits to create better digital experiences and rethink their UX processes. He is a frequent organizer, presenter, volunteer, and mentor at UX-related events. In 2013, Jimmy relocated from Arlington, VA to Brooklyn, NY with his wife Nicole, aka @coolacctngchick. You can learn more about Jimmy by following him on Twitter @uxprinciples.
results.name: Suggested Event: What Going Out To Eat Teaches Us About UX Design

results.description:
We'll be having 2 talks for this meetup!  Woo Hoo!

How to Tackle Legacy Code

Often you aren’t going to be building brand new web applications but rather adding or extending features for existing ones.  Working with large monolithic rails applications can be difficult. It’s often hard to track down the code you need to be working on and even more difficult to understand the code once you’ve found it.

Katherin Siracusa and Kyle Doherty, junior developers at AlphaSights, will talk about the struggles they had when they were thrown into large legacy codebases for the first time and techniques they’ve learned to tackle them.


this, call, and bind in JavaScript

An explanation through examples of `this` in JavaScript and some functions that manipulate it.

presented by Rory O'Kane

This is not a self-improvement course - it's a series intended to help you develop your inherent nature by recognizing your kindness, connection, and wisdom. Everything you're looking for is already here, let us help you discover it.

This six-week course, 10/28-12/9, incorporates western psychological techniques with traditional contemplative practices to help you develop a healthy relationship to yourself and others. 

Though compassion is often regarded as a weak and cowardly response to difficult people and situations, traditional practices and modern psychological research suggest that compassion is the most effective and courageous quality for creating respectful and loving relationships.  With this unique offering, we’ll learn how to use discernment to create healthy boundaries, how to work with guilt and shame, and how to work with judgement and criticism with understanding and patience. 


You can drop in to any class for $20.  Brainiacs can register for the entire six week series at a discounted price of $80 by selecting the "Basic member" option at the below link. 


More details and registration:

http://theidproject.org/events/2015/10/28/compassionate-relationships

We are located on the 2nd floor of a walk-up building.  There is no elevator.  Cushions and chairs will be provided.

results.description:
Having done well in our first outing at the trivia night in Meatballs & Brews at Rahway, we're planning to return not only to retain bragging rights but also to claim our prize ($20 restaurant certificate to be used only at the next week).  True to the trope of the restaurant's signature cuisine (meatballs!), most of the trivia teams jumped at the chance to brandish their lexicographical gymnastics to arrive at team names--The Ballerz & Rhapsody in Blue Balls being our teams' contributions.

The trivia starts around 7:30-45, and the format (if things remain consistent from week to week) is 5 rounds, each containing a bonus question:

• 1st Half: 6 questions of different categories, each wagered from 1-6 (no repeats)


• Handout Round: This past week, it was a word scramble on musical instruments


• 2nd Half: 6 questions (likely w/ a common theme), each wagered from 2-12 (on the even numbers, no repeats).  There's a chance that this is designed to be an audio-based round, depending on if it repeats next week.


• Current Events: 4 questions, 5 pts each


• Final Round: 2 questions, each wagered between 0-12


 Parking options include street parking (which seems to be free after 7pm), lot parking ($1?) and garage parking.  

Hope you can make it, and look forward to seeing you there!
results.name: Rahway Trivia: Reprise of "Rhapsody in Blue Balls"

Join us for the general meeting and some delicious pizza as we celebrate our annual "Non-Thanksgiving Thanksgiving".

Here are the details:

Date: Nov 18th (3rd Wednesday)
Time: 7:15pm
Location: Care One Cupola (Theater Room)
100 W. Ridgewood Ave
Paramus, NJ 07652

****PLEASE NOTE OUR NEW LOCATION*****

We start with our small discussion group at 7:15pm. A great place for new parents to ask questions and get some amazing feedback.

A brief business meeting will follow then enjoy a hot meal with friends before the holiday stress arrives.

$5 will be collected at the meeting to cover the cost of the pizza.

results.description:
Please join us on Wednesday evening for a 6ish mile, casual-pace loop run.

Don't be intimidated by the title. This is still a go-at-your-own pace run, with stops and looping back for people. We just kindly suggest that you take it at your not-so-casual pace, whatever that may mean to you.

We will meet just inside the 52nd Street entrance to Windmuller Park at 7:15pm and head out for a 6ish mile loop through Woodside, Sunnyside, LIC, and Greenpoint, before returning to the start. 

For our evening runs, we will wait up to 10 minutes to allow for late-arrivals. This can mean we will wait for 2 minutes or 10. Please be prompt. 

If there is interest after we complete our run, we may venture to a pub for snacks and/or beverages.


- - - - - - 
 Please see our full calendar of events
http://www.woodsidesunnysiderunners.com/events/calendar/
connect with us on Google+
http://www.google.com/+WoodsideSunnysideRunners
like us on Facebook
https://www.facebook.com/WoodsideSunnysideRunners
and follow us on Instagram
https://instagram.com/woodsidesunnysiderunners/

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
